Description: Tondo sherd (mended from two fragments and added plaster) with top of stem of Attic red-figured pottery type A cup; interior: red-figure decoration consisting of satyr (frontal head; black relief bobbles for hair on skull) lifting maenad (wearing spotted garment and spotted panther skin with paws hanging on left and head on right) holding a spotted snake with red forked tongue in her left hand and a branch with small red leaves in her right; exterior: glazed black, torus at junction of bowl and stem, set off by reserved grooves top and bottom; inside of stem black with reserved band at junction with reserved underside; ancient repair hole in each sherd.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1888,0601.604 (E812.1) and belongs to the same vase as Cambridge, Fitzwilliam GR. 142.1899. For the animal skin shown reserved behind the figures, see Vierneisel, K. and Kaeser, B., Kunst der Schale. Kultur des Trinkens. Munich 1990, 404, fig. 71.12.
Bibliographic references: Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 63-4)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 508, no. C68)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 236, no. 6a)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0642) (Phase 1)
